questions.text: Why does this product exist?
questions.findings: Acme Corp is building an invoice processing platform to reduce manual data entry. Customer interviews revealed that finance teams spend 40% of their time on manual invoice processing. The core problem is the lack of automated extraction and validation of invoice data.
questions.notes: Key insight: Finance teams are frustrated with repetitive data entry tasks

questions.text: Who actually experiences the problem we are solving?
questions.findings: Primary users are Accounts Payable clerks and Finance Managers in mid-market companies (50-500 employees). They process 200-500 invoices per month. Secondary stakeholders include CFOs who need real-time visibility into payables.
questions.notes: Persona: AP Clerk processing 200+ invoices monthly

questions.text: How do we know this problem is worth solving now?
questions.findings: Market research shows 73% of mid-market companies still use manual invoice processing. Competitors are gaining traction. Customer interviews confirm urgent pain point with 8/10 rating average.

questions.text: What decision are we trying to enable or change?
questions.findings: Enable faster approval workflows. Currently invoices sit in queues for 5-7 days. Target: same-day processing for 80% of invoices.

questions.text: What alternatives do users have today?
What's been tried before and why did it fail?
What would good look like three months from now?
questions.findings: 3-month success criteria: 70% reduction in manual data entry time, 95% invoice extraction accuracy, and positive NPS from pilot customers. Team aligned on these metrics during planning workshop.

questions.text: What success would look like in a (insert time period)?
questions.findings: 6-month target: 50 paying customers, $100K ARR, 90% customer retention. 12-month: 200 customers, $500K ARR.

questions.text: How will we know this worked?
questions.findings: Key metrics: Time-to-process per invoice, extraction accuracy rate, user adoption rate. We have baseline data from current manual process (avg 8 min/invoice). A/B testing planned for automation vs manual processing.
questions.notes: Dashboard being built to track these metrics

questions.text: The team's relationship with metrics
What is the team actually measuring today?
Do we have baseline data to compare against?
Does the team have the tools/infrastructure to measure outcomes?
How long does it take to know if something worked?
How do we know our changes caused the outcome vs external factors?
Are we tracking leading indicators or only lagging ones?
Where product ownership actually lives today?
Role clarity across PO, PMs, and engineers
Who decides when priorities collide?
How intentional the backlog really is?
Are key stakeholders aligned on the vision and priorities?
How do decisions and learnings get shared across the org?
Are there overlapping features or capabilities across products?
The team's and leadership's appetite for challenge vs safety
questions.findings: Team shows high appetite for innovation but leadership is risk-averse due to recent failed project. Need to build confidence through small wins. Recommend incremental delivery with frequent demos.
questions.notes: Previous project failure still affecting team morale

questions.text: How much autonomy the team believes they have?
How the team currently defines value
Team's past failures or trauma (did a big project fail?)
Hidden stakeholders who actually control decisions
Budget or resource constraints that nobody talks about
Technical debt or system constraints limiting autonomy
Geographic or org structure issues (distributed teams, cross functional friction)
How often does the team directly interact with customers/users?
questions.findings: Currently minimal direct customer contact - only through support tickets. No regular user research cadence. Team relies on stakeholder assumptions about user needs. This is a significant gap that needs addressing.
questions.notes: CRITICAL GAP - Need to establish regular customer touchpoints

questions.text: What external dependencies could block or delay progress?
How does the team currently learn and experiment?
Does the team have the capabilities needed for this work?
Are there hard external deadlines driving this work?
What assumptions are we making that we have not tested?
questions.findings:
UNTESTED ASSUMPTIONS:
1. Users will trust AI-extracted data without manual verification
2. Integration with existing ERP systems will be straightforward
3. Customers will pay premium pricing for automation

RECOMMENDATION: Run prototype tests with 3 pilot customers before full development.
questions.notes: High priority - validate before major investment
